title: 103_s1274
content:
The Small Business Guaranteed Credit Enhancement Act of 1993 includes provisions such as general authorizations, authority to impose secondary market fees, penalties, and the authority to reduce loan guarantee percentages. It also involves a study and report, amendments to the microloan program, the Small Business Development Center Program, the White House Conference on Small Business, and the National Women's Business Council. SEC. 2 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase funding amounts in various subsections. SEC. 3 grants authority to impose secondary market fees. The Small Business Act is amended to allow the Administration to collect additional guarantee fees for loan guarantees sold in the secondary market. The fees include a percentage of the outstanding principal amount and a portion of the sale price exceeding 110 percent of the principal amount. The Administration can collect fees for central registration functions to reduce loan subsidies under section 7(a) of the Act. Fees cannot be charged to borrowers with guaranteed loans. Late payment penalties can be imposed. Any new fees imposed by the Administration for central registration functions under section 7(a) of the Small Business Act will only apply to loans sold in the secondary market after August 31, 1993. SEC. 4. PENALTIES.

The Administration can allow lenders to charge a penalty fee for late payments on guaranteed loans, not exceeding 5% of the monthly payment plus interest.

SEC. 5. AUTHORITY TO REDUCE LOAN GUARANTEE PERCENTAGES. The Small Business Act is amended to require specific guarantee percentages for financing based on amount and maturity period, with the Administration able to reduce participation below 75 percent upon lender request. The Small Business Act is amended to specify guarantee percentages for loans based on amount and maturity period. The Administration can reduce participation below 85 percent upon lender request. The maximum interest rate for loans under the Preferred Lenders Program is capped at the rate determined by the Administration for other loan guarantees under section 7(a). The Small Business Act is amended to specify guarantee percentages for loans based on amount and maturity period. The amendments made by subsection (a) regarding loan guarantees under section 7(a) will be effective September 1, 1993. Loan guarantee applications received before August 21, 1993, are not applicable to these amendments. The Administration will aggregate the outstanding guaranteed principal of multiple loan guarantees issued to the same borrower to determine the percent of the loan to be guaranteed. SEC. 6. STUDY AND REPORT. The Administration will study and evaluate the impact of the amendments on small businesses, especially those owned by minorities and women, in obtaining financing and the growth of the secondary market. A report will be submitted to the Committees on Small Business annually, including findings on changes in interest rates for small businesses. The Administration will study the impact of amendments on small businesses owned by minorities and women in obtaining financing and growing the secondary market. Findings and recommendations will be segregated by ethnic and gender components. The term "small business concerns owned and controlled by minorities" includes businesses owned by individuals from designated groups listed in the Small Business Act. SEC. 7. REPEALER. Sections 3 and 5 of this Act will be repealed on September 30, 1996. SEC. 8. MICROLOAN PROGRAM AMENDMENTS. Amendments to the Small Business Act include increasing the loan amount to $25,000, increasing the number of grants to 25 for up to 5 years, and changing the interest rate to 7 percent. SEC. 9. SMALL BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT CENTER PROGRAM. (a) Clearinghouse.--Section 21(c)(7) of the Small Business Act is amended to allow the Administration to make grants or cooperative agreements with centers for up to five years. Matching funds provisions do not apply to these grants. 
(b) Authorization.--Section 25(i) of the Small Business Act is amended to allocate $2,000,000 for each of fiscal years 1993 and 1994. Section 223 of the Small Business Credit and Business Opportunity Enhancement Act of 1992 is amended by removing the last sentence of subsection (b) for fiscal years 1993 and 1994. The White House Conference on Small Business Authorization Act is amended to change the dates for the conference and the appointment of individuals to the Commission. Additionally, the National Women's Business Council is mentioned. SEC. 11. NATIONAL WOMEN'S BUSINESS COUNCIL. Section 407 of the Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is amended to authorize $500,000 for fiscal year 1993 and 1994. New spending authority is limited and this section will cease to be effective on November 30, 1995.
